posts.title: What does Trump victory mean for AT&T-Time Warner?
posts.text:
What does Trump victory mean for AT&T-Time Warner? Trump had publicly blasted AT&T’s proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner Post to Facebook What does Trump victory mean for AT&T-Time Warner? Trump had publicly blasted AT&T’s proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner  //usat.ly/2fCVdm7   Join the Nation's Conversation   What does Trump victory mean for AT&T-Time Warner? Edward C. Baig , USA TODAY 12:49 p.m. EST November 9, 2016 x Share What will a Donald Trump White House look like? Veuer's Josh King looks takes a closer look at possible cabinet picks and the history behind building a team. Buzz60 
NEW YORK—Candidate Donald Trump had publicly blasted AT&T’s proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner, saying the blockbuster merger concentrated too much power in the hands of too few. The question now is will President Trump stick to that belief? 
Time Warner (TWX) stock was down 1.32% in early afternoon trading. AT&T (ATT) shares on the other hand were up 0.74%. 
As part of the stock and cash transaction announced last month, AT&T agreed to pay Time Warner shareholders $107.50 per share. 
AT&T Chief Financial Officer John Stephens told a Wells Fargo tech conference audience Wednesday that AT&T was “optimistic” that regulators would approve the deal. “From a company perspective, we really look forward to working with President-Elect Trump and his transition team. His policies, his discussions about infrastructure investment, economic development, and American innovation all fit right in with AT&Ts goals.” 
Time Warner declined a USA TODAY request for comment. 
Given his background, the expectation is that Trump, backed by GOP lawmakers, will bring a pro-business bent to the White House, raising the possibility that his remarks against the deal may have been populist campaign rhetoric, especially since Time Warner owns CNN, and that he might be more inclined to move forward. That remains of course to be seen. 
Several Democratic leaders had also voiced opposition to the proposed merger. 
Says Recon Analytics telecom analyst Roger Entner: “I think we have to wait until we have an attorney general and new chief of the antitrust bureau because they’re taking the lead on this.” 
If the deal does end up getting regulatory approval--a major if--it could close sometime late next year.

thread.title: Could a President Trump bust a potential AT&T-Time Warner deal?
thread.title_full: Could a President Trump bust a potential AT&T-Time Warner deal?

posts.author: Ken Fang
posts.title: Could a President Trump bust a potential AT&T-Time Warner deal?
posts.text:
Mark Cuban revokes credentials from two ESPN reporters for no good reason Now that Donald Trump has been elected President, there are several stances he took during the campaign to see if he follows through as the Chief Executive of the United States. One of them was regarding the AT&T purchase of Time Warner. During an October 22 speech, Trump fully addressed the idea: 
“As an example of the power structure I’m fighting, AT&T is buying Time Warner and thus CNN — a deal we will not approve in my administration because it’s too much concentration of power in the hands of too few.” 
Trump has set his targets on the media throughout the campaign, in particular CNN which is owned by Time Warner as well as Comcast which purchased NBCUniversal in 2011. Trump said he would also look to break up Comcast saying it was too big. 
AT&T is hoping to purchase Time Warner to help it provide content for its DirecTV satellite system and DirecTV Now streaming service which is expected to launch later this year. 
Now, if Trump follows through, it could stop a wave of media mergers and acquisitions. But AT&T says it’s hoping that Trump will be amenable to its purchase. AT&T Chief Finnacial Officer John Stephens told investors that he’s still optimistic that the deal will be approved. 
The AT&T deal has to await federal approval so we’ll see how a Trump Administration handles it, deciding to disapprove or to sign off. 
If it goes through, AT&T will have a hold on plenty of content including sports programming like Turner Sports properties like MLB, NBA, NCAA Tournament and the PGA Championship and HBO Sports programming like boxing, Real Sports and documentaries as well digital properties like Bleacher Report and The Ringer. 
It’s going to an interesting 2017 for deals. 
[ Bloomberg ] About Ken Fang Ken has been covering the sports media in earnest at his own site, Fang's Bites since May 2007 and at Awful Announcing since March 2013. He provides a unique perspective having been an award-winning radio news reporter in Providence and having worked in local television. Fang celebrates the three Boston Red Sox World Championships in the 21st Century, but continues to be a long-suffering Cleveland Browns fan.

thread.title: Trump doesn’t like the media. He certainly doesn’t like media mergers.
thread.title_full: Trump doesn’t like the media. He certainly doesn’t like media mergers.

posts.author: Edmund Lee
posts.title: Trump doesn’t like the media. He certainly doesn’t like media mergers.
posts.text: Trump doesn’t like the media. He certainly doesn’t like media mergers. No AT&T deal for Time Warner. Also, Comcast breakup from NBCUniversal? share Photo by Darren Hauck/Getty Images Let’s get this big caveat out of the way: Donald Trump probably isn’t interested in the minutiae of being president — that is to say the actual, everyday management of the most powerful state on earth. His cabinet will end up exercising far more power than any unelected body ever has in the U.S. But it’s worth examining what Trump himself has said, since we still believe in the public process of a democracy — if he’s said it out loud, it’s fair game. It’s clear Trump doesn’t like the media. He certainly doesn’t like media mergers. In the first 100 days of his presidency, he vowed to block AT&T’s proposed acquisition of Time Warner , arguing it “concentrates too much power in the hands of too few.” That makes Trump come across like a First Amendment evangelist, but more likely there’s a deeper, more personal animus motivating this position. Time Warner owns CNN, which he’s blamed for negative stories and for being in Clinton’s camp. The network became a prime target among Trump supporters in the last few months of his campaign as chants of “ CNN sucks! ” became a popular rallying cry at his events. ( There was another media chant, too .) Trump added: "Deals like this destroy democracy.” He also said he’d break up Comcast and NBCUniversal (an investor in Recode owner Vox Media), with his campaign maligning MSNBC as a “Clinton megaphone.” To be clear, Trump does not actually have an ideology. He at once comes across as a pro-business outsider favoring lower taxes and less regulation, while also pushing the notion he’s a pro-consumer apparatchik looking out for a free and fair press. He’s neither. Trump is a vain pragmatist who simultaneously craves and reviles the media’s attention. This great Trump interview from a few years ago reveals just how obsessed he’d become after first seeing his name in print: “I loved it. ... I don’t think there’s anything wrong with that. I thought it was amazing. … It felt good.” Today, there’s little evidence he’s against the AT&T-Time Warner deal for the sake of democracy. Still, will it be blocked? As I outlined at the top, Trump may never actually follow through on anything he’s said in the campaign. If he does, Trump would have to create a new antitrust doctrine to block AT&T’s deal for Time Warner. Currently, the law and precedent are on AT&T’s side. The deal doesn’t change or limit consumer choice, what’s known as a “vertical merger,” so there isn’t, broadly speaking, a threat of creating a monopoly. The same logic was applied to Comcast’s ownership of NBCUniversal. I’ve talked before about why AT&T’s purchase of Time Warner doesn’t make sense , and by that same argument (that it actually doesn’t help AT&T), there shouldn’t be any regulatory reason why it shouldn’t pass. There is, however, a growing faction in D.C. that does favor a new antitrust standard for mergers: If the combination is too big, regardless of whether it maintains a consumer’s choice, it should still be blocked. James Stewart of the New York Times does a good job of outlining such a possibility . There are other media deals in the works that could also come under Trump’s gaze. Viacom and CBS are looking at a merger , and it’s likely Disney will look for some kind of deal as well, even if it’s unlikely to buy Vice . If Trump does go all out on AT&T (and Comcast), he’d be aligning himself with some unusual political bedfellows: Senators Bernie Sanders and Al Franken, both of whom oppose the merger. recode_divider

thread.title: Will Trump follow through on his promise to block AT&T's planned acquisition of Time Warner?
thread.title_full: Will Trump follow through on his promise to block AT&T's planned acquisition of Time Warner?

posts.author: Alan F.
posts.title: Will Trump follow through on his promise to block AT&T's planned acquisition of Time Warner?
posts.text: › Will Trump follow through on his promise to block AT&T's planned acquisition of Time Warner? Will Trump follow through on his promise to block AT&T's planned acquisition of Time Warner? Posted: Tags : AT&T - AT&T + When AT&T announced that it was purchasing Time Warner for $85.4 billion last month , Donald Trump promised to block the deal if he was elected president, saying that "It's too much concentration of power in the hands of too few." At the time, it seemed like a threat that AT&T wouldn't have to deal with. But following the shocking election results on Tuesday night, the carrier's plans now seem up in the air.One of the properties involved in the purchase, 24-hour cable news service CNN was decidedly pro-Clinton throughout the campaign. Trump could decide to block the deal just for revenge. In his original statement, he said that the AT&T bid for Time Warner was an example of how the "power structure" was rigged against him. Besides CNN, some of the other properties that AT&T is looking to pick up in the deal include the Warner Brothers Studio, HBO, TNT, TBS and 10% of streaming video company Hulu. Content is important in mobile, and the nation's second largest carrier would be picking up a treasure trove of content if the deal goes through.About 30 months ago, AT&T acquired DirecTV for $48.5 billion , picking up 142 million wireless subscribers and 38 million pay TV subscribers. In July, Verizon purchased Yahoo for $4.83 billion. "From a company perspective, we really look forward to working with President-elect Trump and his transition team. Policies and discussions about infrastructure investment, economic development and American innovation all fit right in with AT&T’s goals…. We’ve been the leading investor in this country for more than five years running. We look forward with optimism to working with the leadership and providing benefits to our customers and shareholders."-John Stephens, CFO, AT&T Historically, Republican administrations have been pro-business and pro-merger. But Trump won the presidency as a political outsider, which means that past rules do not apply.

thread.title: What are the odds of AT&T-Time Warner merger's approval? Famed Wall Street investor weighs in
thread.title_full: What are the odds of AT&T-Time Warner merger's approval? Famed Wall Street investor weighs in

posts.author: Melissa Repko
posts.title: What are the odds of AT&T-Time Warner merger's approval? Famed Wall Street investor weighs in
posts.text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Billionaire Wall Street investor Mario Gabelli said he's betting on approval of the AT&T and Time Warner merger, pointing to regulatory changes that may come under the administration of president-elect Donald Trump. 
In an interview on CNBC's Squawk Box on Friday, Gabelli -- who owns stock in AT&T and Time Warner -- gave the merger a 70 percent chance of approval. He said the odds have increased because Tom Wheeler, the current chairman of the U.S. Federal Communications Commission, will step down as part of the transition to a Republican president. 
Gabelli is chairman and CEO of New York-based Gamco Investors. He owns 4 million shares of Time Warner and 2.9 million shares of AT&T. In a previous CNBC interview, he said "we're a cheerleader for both companies." 
He said he expects the AT&T-Time Warner deal to usher in similar large mergers and acquisitions. 
The FCC regulates interstate and international communications by radio, TV, wire, satellite and cable. The government agency is led by five commissioners, who are appointed by the president and confirmed by the U.S. Senate. Will FCC's 'serious concerns' derail AT&T's video service DirecTV Now? 
When a new president is elected, the makeup of the FCC shifts. It's customary for the chairman to step down and for the president to pick a new chairman of his same political party. Only three of the five commissioners can be of the same political party at any time. All of the commissioners have five-year terms. 
On Wednesday, the FCC told AT&T it had "serious concerns" about an AT&T program that waives data charges for customers who use two online TV apps that AT&T owns. AT&T already allows the practice, called "zero-rating," for AT&T wireless and TV customers who use the DirecTV app. The FCC said the practice "may obstruct competition and harm consumers." It asked AT&T to respond to concerns by Nov. 21.

thread.title: AT&T: If It Isn't Broke, Don't Fix It
thread.title_full: AT&T: If It Isn't Broke, Don't Fix It

posts.title: AT&T: If It Isn't Broke, Don't Fix It
posts.text:
AT&T agreed to acquire Time Warner, but the deal looks to be at risk. 
The DirecTV acquisition is having a significant impact on the company's operating results. 
AT&T is a long-term buy at today's price. AT&T (NYSE: T ) has been in the news a lot lately, with the most recent buzz being about the proposed deal to acquire Time Warner (NYSE: TWX ), but the one thing that has not been widely covered is the fact that AT&T has been able to report impressive earnings results over the last two years while operating in a very challenging environment. Moreover, AT&T's fundamentals have greatly improved since the 2015 acquisition of DirecTV and it looks like this trend is set to continue well into 2017. One of the biggest takeaways from the last few quarters is just how impactful the DirecTV acquisition has already been to AT&T's operating results (more on this below). So, I question why management would want to significantly increase the company's risk profile by acquiring Time Warner at a point in time when AT&T's future already looks bright. Acquiring Time Warner could indeed provide some great long-term benefits (Liberty Media's Chairman Mr. John Malone seems to think so too ), but, in my opinion, AT&T staying status quo may be the best option for this company. If It Isn't Broke, Don't Fix It On October 22, 2016, AT&T reported Q3 2016 adjusted EPS of $0.74, which was in line with analyst estimates. For comparison purposes, AT&T reported adjusted EPS of $0.74 in the same quarter in the prior year. Click to enlarge (Source: Fidelity) This makes it the eighth consecutive quarter that AT&T has been able to meet or beat the consensus earnings estimate. In the most recent quarter, AT&T's results showed improvements almost across the board, but, in my opinion, the best is still yet to come. AT&T reported a ~5% YoY increase in revenue and ~2% increase in cash from operations, which were both positively impacted by the game-changing DirecTV acquisition . The DirecTV Acquisition Is Working, So Why Try To Mess Up A Good Thing? This acquisition has greatly impacted AT&T's operating results over the last few quarters, and this was again the case in the most recent quarter. Not only has the acquisition impacted AT&T's top line but it has also allowed for AT&T to report earnings growth and improve its cash flow metrics. Click to enlarge (Source: AT&T's Q3 2016 Financial & Operational Results Report ) The nine months ended September 30, 2016 ratio of 67% may not appear to be a great figure, but let's not forget that this same ratio for the nine months ended September 30, 2014, which was the year before the DirecTV acquisition was approved/finalized, was over 80% . The improvements in the cash flow metrics are largely a result of management properly managing the company's capex and cost structure, which was a topic that was well-covered by management during the conference call . Management mentioned that the company is in line to achieve the $2.5b cost synergy target by 2017 and they highlighted the fact that the company was ahead of schedule in relation to the $1.5b cost synergy target for the current year. AT&T has steadily improved its cash flow metrics since acquiring DirecTV and management expects for the cash flow dividend coverage to be under 70% for full year 2016. However, the benefits from the DirecTV acquisition were not the only positive developments for the quarter, because AT&T again reported improving results for the international operations. International Operations, Already Showing Promise AT&T is still in the early innings of its international expansion efforts, but the company reported encouraging results again this quarter. The company reported over 700k net adds, which helped bring the total wireless subscriber number to 10.7m. (Source: Q3 2016 Earnings Presentation ) AT&T is building a strong foundation for its international operations and the company is already beating several internal targets/benchmarks. More importantly, the company's international operations are already becoming more profitable and the international cash flow metrics have greatly improved YoY (i.e. DirecTV Latin America is now cash flow positive). As I described in " AT&T: The Path Is Becoming Clearer , " AT&T has a real opportunity to grow the international operations into a material portion of the company's consolidated results within the next few years. So far, so good. AT&T is firing on all cylinders with the DirecTV integration going well and the international operations already showing promise, especially given the challenging wireless environment and the changing pay-TV space, but the one thing that could quickly change my positive view of AT&T's long-term business prospects is if the company takes on too much risk by adding Time Warner into the fold. The Deal Makes Sense, But That Does Not Mean That It Should Be Done The details of the T-TWX deal have already been well-covered here on SA (see here and here for two recent articles on the deal) so I will not bore you all by going over the same details. The biggest concern, in my mind, is the amount of debt that AT&T would have to take on to acquire Time Warner, but it does not stop there because this type of deal brings significant integration and operational risks that also need to be considered. At the end of the day, I do think that a T-TWX tie-up makes sense from a content standpoint (i.e. Time Warner's content would differentiate the DirecTV Now service from what competitors are offering/will offer) but I believe that the deal is too risky and that there are still too many open questions. That's why I think that the Donald Trump victory may be one of the best things to happen to AT&T investors ( full disclosure: I was not a Trump supporter but, as an American, I will fully support our soon-to-be president). The president-elect is likely to block the proposed deal and this should be viewed as good news for shareholders because it will not only save the company from a years-long battle with regulators on a deal that may not be approved (many are predicting that the deal will not be approved) but it will also prevent management from making a mistake that could have a lasting impact on AT&T's long-term prospects. Bottom Line AT&T has been able to report improving results over the last two years, and the company's future looks even brighter, so I have serious reservations about the Time Warner deal. On one hand, I am happy that management is not sitting on their hands while the pay-TV landscape is changing at a rapid pace, but, on the other hand, I do not necessarily believe that paying a steep premium for Time Warner is warranted. The DirecTV Now service appears to have promising prospects , so I would much rather see AT&T take the less-risky approach of licensing content instead of taking on too much risk by acquiring a large content provider. The DirecTV acquisition is already paying huge dividends and the international efforts are already bearing fruit so I believe that there is already a clear path for this company to create additional shareholder value in the years ahead. AT&T shares are up ~8% on a YTD basis, but there is still room for shares to run. As such, long-term investors should treat any significant pullbacks as buying opportunities. If you found this article to be informative and would like to hear more about this company or any other company that I analyze, please consider hitting the "Follow" button above. thread.title: AT&T to Gain Unfair Advantage With Time Warner (T, TWX)
thread.title_full: AT&T to Gain Unfair Advantage With Time Warner (T, TWX)

posts.author: Richard Saintvilus
posts.title: AT&T to Gain Unfair Advantage With Time Warner (T, TWX)
posts.text:
AT&T to Gain Unfair Advantage With Time Warner (T, TWX) By Richard Saintvilus | November 11, 2016 — 8:44 AM EST 
AT&T, Inc.'s ( T ) $85.5 billion blockbuster acquisition of media giant Time Warner Inc. ( TWX ) sent shockwaves throughout market, sending media investors scrambling to wonder who's next. 
Although there's speculation about whether president-elect Donald Trump could seek to block the deal, Federal regulators may take their time to review the possible unfair advantages AT&T would gain over competitors like Verizon Communications Inc. ( VZ ) and Dish Network Corp. ( DISH ). (See also: AT&T CFO Says He Can Work With Trump .) 
Several AT&T competitors have already complained about the company's tactics that exempt its own video services from affecting its users' data plans. AT&T allows customers to watch video on DirecTV apps on their AT&T cell phones without eating into monthly data allotments. And the company is expected to do the same with an upcoming TV streaming service called DirecTV Now, for which it will charge $35 per month. 
That's a massive advantage given that AT&T now owns DirecTV. In a letter to AT&T dated Wednesday, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) said that the practice of exempting its users from data caps may ultimately hurt consumers. The FCC asked that AT&T reply to its concerns by Nov. 21. 
On Thursday, AT&T said that the practice actually helps consumers, rather than hurt them, since they gain from watching video without using up their data. Any video provider can pay AT&T, "at [the company's] lowest wholesale rates," to let customers watch without using up their AT&T data, said AT&T executive Bob Quinn in an emailed statement, according to the Associated Press. (See also: Can AT&T Fund Its $85.5B Time Warner Purchase? ) 
However, if AT&T also takes over Time Warner's video assets, it would give AT&T a level of strength to dictate not only data-plan pricing on the mobile side of the business, but it could also re-introduce debates over net neutrality . What's more, the deal now casts a shadow over the broader mergers and acquisitions (M&A) market. And how the deal unfolds may dictate M&A policies under this new administration. 
Time Warner shares closed Thursday at $86.33, down 0.31%, while AT&T shares closed at $36.57, down 2.32% Subscribe to News To Use for the latest insights and analysis Thanks for signing up to Investopedia Insights - News to Use.

thread.title: AT&T-Time Warner merger: government regulation
thread.title_full: AT&T-Time Warner merger: government regulation - Business Insider

posts.author: Nathan McAlone
posts.title: AT&T-Time Warner merger: government regulation
posts.text:
Getty/Alex Wong
AT&T wants to buy Time Warner in a monster $85 billion deal, but some are concerned the government, particularly under Donald Trump, will move to block it.
“In an example of the power structure I’m fighting, AT&T is buying Time Warner and thus CNN — a deal we will not approve in my administration because it’s too much concentration of power in the hands of too few,” Trump said while campaigning.
AT&T, however, is telling Wall Street not to worry.
At RBC's recent Technology, Internet, Media and Telecommunications (TIMT) Conference in New York, AT&T management suggested there wouldn't be any trouble with the merger.
The FCC question One big reason AT&T is smiling is because the company believes the merger won't be under the jurisdiction of the FCC.
"The only scenario in which the FCC would have jurisdiction is if Time Warner transfers certain broadcast licenses to AT&T," RBC analyst Jonathan Atkin, who viewed the presentation by AT&T's Chris Womack and Michael Black, wrote. "The company believes these licenses (primarily business radio licenses and licenses related to Time Warner’s ownership of the WPCN superstation) can be offloaded easily, obviating the need for an FCC review."
That would mean the merger would only need to clear the Department of Justice, which AT&T is optimistic about.
"The major difference between an FCC and DOJ review is that a DOJ review provides AT&T legal recourse while the FCC, if it chooses not to support the deal can defer the issue to an administrative law judge, a process that can last upwards of three years, usually resulting in the dissolution of the deal," Atkin wrote.
AT&T likes its odds, and expects the timeline on the merger to be 12-14 months.
Why Time Warner? In the presentation, AT&T also outlined some of the rationale for the Time Warner deal.
Here's the most interesting bit: "AT&T hopes to strengthen its quad-play offering by zero-rating Time Warner content, which the company believes will provide consumers an incentive to adopt the AT&T bundle," Atkin wrote.
"Zero-rating" is when wireless carriers don't count data used with certain streaming services against your data cap. So for AT&T-Time Warner, it could mean that you never have to pay for data to watch HBO. You won't have to worry about data overages when you're watching "Game of Thrones."
This sounds great for the customer on the surface, but the FCC has said it has " serious concerns " about the way AT&T is using zero-rating, particularly with regards to its upcoming DirecTV Now streaming TV service.
Why?
AT&T has said it will treat its rivals (and friends) equally when it comes to zero-rating. That likely means that every company, from Netflix to Showtime, will have to pay a certain fee to have their video zero-rated. No freebies for HBO. But since AT&T would own HBO, that "fee" money would just be shifting from one pocket of AT&T to another. That's a place AT&T could potentially act anti-competitively.
AT&T provided a few other reasons for the Time Warner merger, as well. Here they are:
AT&T thinks it could help reduce churn (cancellations) in its wireless business. It could help AT&T maintain control of content distribution in the face of potential rivals like Amazon, Google, and Facebook, as video shifts toward over-the-top (OTT) delivery. AT&T thinks it can boost ad revenue. " In internal trials, the company has successfully increased sales of certain products by as much as 80% through targeted advertising," Atkin wrote. SEE ALSO: AT&T will give away free Apple TVs and Fire Sticks with its new $35 streaming TV service NOW WATCH: Obama: 'We are going to have to guard against a rise in a crude sort of nationalism' Time Warner AT&T Mergers And Acquisitions Antitrust doj FCC Donald Trump

We’ll take a closer look at the key factors that are driving growth for Time Warner. We’ll also look at the financial metrics, key technical indicators, valuation metrics, and analyst ratings for Time Warner.

posts.text:
How the Time Warner Acquisition Could Benefit AT&T PART 2 OF 13 What’s the Advertising Outlook for Time Warner’s Turner Business? By Shirley Pelts | Nov 17, 2016 3:18 pm EST Reduction in TV advertising loads 
Many media companies like Time Warner ( TWX ) have been talking about reducing advertising loads on television. At the start of 2016, Time Warner said it intends to reduce ad loads on Turner’s TNT channel. It also intends to reduce ads on TNT’s three new dramas set to premiere this year. The company’s truTV channel has already been targeting the reduction of advertising loads by 50%. 
The company stated at its fiscal 3Q16 earnings call that the responses to its reduced advertising strategy have been encouraging from both viewers and advertisers. Time Warner also indicated that advertisers are still willing to advertise on Turner networks mainly due to television’s wide audience reach and engagement. The company also stated that its program ratings are up and it has observed “higher consumer satisfaction and higher brand recall” among viewers. Advertising outlook for Turner 
Time Warner also stated at its fiscal 3Q16 earnings call that in fiscal 4Q16, it expects its advertising revenue at Turner to be flat. However, its scatter advertising market remains up, with the pricing of advertising slots on its television networks in the United States up in “double-digits over the upfront.” The company also indicated that in fiscal 4Q16, Turner’s TNT network will have “fewer hours of original programming,” which is expected to ramp up in 2017. 
Time Warner also stated that when it comes to international advertising revenues, based on current exchange rates, it expects currency fluctuations to have the same impact as in fiscal 3Q16. In fiscal 3Q16, international advertising revenues remained flat in fiscal 3Q16 for Time Warner’s Turner division. But excluding a drag of eight percentage points from currency fluctuations, it was up year-over-year in “high-single digits.” 
As the above chart indicates, advertising revenues comprised 38% of Turner’s total revenues of $2.6 billion in fiscal 3Q16. Advertising revenues for Turner were $996 million in fiscal 3Q16.  ["TWX"],"ticker_names":["Time Warner Inc."]}

thread.title: Will the AT&T and Time Warner Merger Survive the FCC?
thread.title_full: Will the AT&T and Time Warner Merger Survive the FCC?

posts.title: Will the AT&T and Time Warner Merger Survive the FCC?
posts.text:
By Casey C. Sullivan, Esq. on November 17, 2016 2:58 PM 
Last month, AT&T announced plans to acquire Time Warner for over $85 billion. The merger, if allowed, would give birth to a massive new telecom and media Goliath, combining one of the nation's biggest content creators with one of its biggest content distributors. 
But, like all mergers, AT&T and Time Warner will have to survive the scrutiny of antitrust authorities at the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission first. And, because Time Warner is a media company, the deal could come under scrutiny from the   Commission, an agency Bloomberg describes as " a graveyard for mergers ." 
Why Worry About the FCC? 
Time Warner's media holdings include everything from HBO to Warner Bros. to CNN to the Cartoon Network. A review by Bloomberg found that Time Warner has dozens of FCC licenses that would trigger FCC review of the planned merger. 
The merger would be reviewed by the federal government, FCC licenses or not, but FCC could increase the likelihood that the merger will not be successful, since FCC merger review is considered particularly difficult, even " Kafkaesque ," killing mergers by delaying them until they're no longer viable. 
A new Trump administration probably won't mean a friendly environment for the AT&T-Time Warner merger, either. On the campaign trail, President-elect Donald Trump promised to block the deal, saying, "It's too much concentration of power in the hands of too few." That statement, as the Wall Street Journal notes , is in contrast with his pledge to deregulate the telecom industry, leaving many to wonder what position the administration will actually take. 
How the Merger Could Avoid FCC Review 
FCC review is triggered if Time Warner transfers its licenses as part of the acquisition. To avoid that, the company could simply offload its licenses. Bloomberg presents one possible scenario: 
In theory, Time Warner could sell its dishes to an unaffiliated third party and enter into a contract with them for the same services -- but in that case, the buyer would need to ask the FCC for a license to provide services in the same location over the same airwaves, said Andrew Jay Schwartzman, senior counselor at the Georgetown University Law Center in Washington. 
It's possible the FCC would accept the application without a fuss, Schwartzman said. But, he said, FCC officials also might say, "Wait a minute! We're not stupid -- you are evading this review." 
But AT&T does see offloading those licenses as the most likely strategy to advancing the merger, it seems. The company presented that as a probable approach last week, according to RBC analyst Jonathan Atkin . Again, evading FCC review would be at the heart of that strategy. 
"The major difference between an FCC and DOJ review is that a DOJ review provides AT&T legal recourse while the FCC, if it chooses not to support the deal, can defer the issue to an administrative law judge, a process that can last upwards of three years, usually resulting in the dissolution of the deal," Atkin says. With the FCC out of the picture, the merger is more likely to take 12 to 14 months to complete.

posts.author: William McConnell
posts.title: How the AT&T-Time Warner Merger May Fare Under the New Administration
posts.text:
President-Elect Donald Trump's picks to search for suitable nominees to staff top federal antitrust and competition posts are good omens for AT&T ( T ) and Time Warner ( TWX ) , the media giants who announced plans to merge last month.
The appointment of staunch conservatives to the transition team won't cheer liberals already distraught by Trump's election. But they do indicate that fair-minded experts in their field will be in charge of telecom and competition policy. They also should dampen fears generated by Trump himself on the campaign trail that he'll use regulatory powers to strike back at media outlets and company officials that clashed with him during the lead-up to the election. When the Time Warner deal was announced Trump said he'd have it blocked if elected.
Heading the efforts to find a new Federal Communication Commission chair and advise the incoming administration on where it should take telecom policy is Jeffrey Eisenach. He is co-chair of economic consulting firm NERA's communications, media, and Internet practice and an adjunct economics professor at George Mason University Law School, where he teaches about regulated industries. He's also a Visiting Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.
Eisenach has served in senior policy positions at the Federal Trade Commission and the White House Office of Management and Budget and served on the 1980-81 Reagan-Bush Transition Team on the FTC and the 2000-2001 Bush-Cheney Transition Team on the Federal Communications Commission.
Serving the Trump Transition Team on staffing the FTC and giving input on the Department of Justice's antitrust picks is former FTC member Joshua Wright, now executive director of the Global Antitrust Institute at George Mason University. Wright served as an FTC commissioner from 2013 to 2015.

thread.title: Will Trump follow through on vow to block AT&T-Time Warner merger?
thread.title_full: Will Trump follow through on vow to block AT&T-Time Warner merger?

posts.author:
Brian Fung
The Washington Post
posts.title: Will Trump follow through on vow to block AT&T-Time Warner merger?
posts.text:
Despite his campaign vows to block the deal, President-elect Donald Trump could be forced to take a friendlier stance on AT&T's $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner than he initially laid out, analysts say -- potentially disappointing supporters who were hoping for a big showdown with the company.
Regulators at the Justice Department are likely to examine the proposed deal closely no matter what happens. But a constellation of factors, from the makeup of Trump's transition team to the mundane details of antitrust law, may make it difficult for Trump to oppose the tie-up once he is in office. As a result, one of the earliest decisions to occur on Trump's watch may be the regulators' approval of the massive acquisition.
Trump blasted the merger at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania last month. "As an example of the power structure I'm fighting," he said, "AT&T is buying Time Warner and thus CNN, a deal we will not approve in my administration because it's too much concentration of power in the hands of too few."
Trump's critique of media consolidation is stoked by fears that the trend may suppress conservative voices. Trump has clashed repeatedly with CNN over its coverage of him, at one point calling the channel "an arm of the Clinton campaign." He derided a CNN documentary about himself as a "total waste of time" and "a joke." But by highlighting CNN -- which is owned by Time Warner -- as a reason to oppose the AT&T deal, Trump risks revealing a personal grudge against CNN's coverage that will not help his administration make an antitrust case, economists say.
"Personal vendettas can't be the basis that you take a case to court," said Hal Singer, an economist and senior fellow at the George Washington Institute for Public Policy.
Trump has targeted other media companies, as well. On the campaign trail, Trump accused Comcast-NBCUniversal of "trying to poison the mind of the American voter," adding that he believes the two companies should never have been allowed to combine. He has also said that Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon's chief executive and owner of The Washington Post, faces "a huge antitrust problem," complaining of The Post's critical coverage and accusing Bezos of using the newspaper to benefit Amazon politically in Washington.
Antitrust experts say these objections do not constitute a compelling antitrust case. In order to challenge AT&T-Time Warner, regulators would need to demonstrate that the transaction poses significant harms to the economy and to competition.
But Trump advisers charged with handling tech policy may not view the AT&T deal in a negative light -- highlighting tensions to come between an outsider candidate and the countless insiders who would likely staff the majority of Trump's administration.
"A lot of these jobs are going to go to establishment Republican types who, ironically, are probably going to just be a continuation of everything he's railed against," said one tech industry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity in order to speak more freely.
One of Trump's earliest hires on tech, Jeffrey Eisenach, is a visiting scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, an elite Republican think tank in Washington. Eisenach's role on Trump's transition team gives him notable sway over the future of the administration's tech policies. The economic researcher's previous clients include the country's largest wireless carrier, Verizon, among others.
Analysts say he has spoken approvingly of big mergers in the past. Eisenach "has been supportive of all the deals in the last few years, including the AT&T/[T-Mobile] and Comcast/Time Warner Cable deals," according to a recent investor note from the analyst firm New Street Research.
That could suggest Eisenach takes a similar view of the AT&T deal, though Eisenach did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
"Either there's going to be mass tension within his team, or he's going to sit back and let the [establishment conservatives] have their way -- in which case, all of his campaign rhetoric on blowing up Comcast and AT&T was just cheap talk," said Singer.
Analysts say AT&T was likely caught off-guard by Trump's victory. "They made a calculated bet with the Hillary administration -- this is not what they expected," said Frank Louthan, an industry analyst at Raymond James. "They may still prevail, but that was a shock."
AT&T has said it stands ready to work with the incoming Trump administration and that their priorities appear aligned. "We really look forward to working with President-elect Trump and his transition team," AT&T chief financial officer John Stephens said at an investor conference Wednesday. "His policies and his discussions about infrastructure investment, economic development, and American innovation all fit right in with AT&T's goals."
  Business Technology Washington Post Donald Trump

thread.title: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is Great For Long-Term AT&T Shareholders But Royally Screws Time Warner Investors
thread.title_full: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is Great For Long-Term AT&T Shareholders But Royally Screws Time Warner Investors

posts.title: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is Great For Long-Term AT&T Shareholders But Royally Screws Time Warner Investors
posts.text:
12.2% Click to enlarge 
The big reason that I own AT&T is that besides the generous and highly secure current yield, I think that AT&T's future cash flows will be able to support much faster dividend growth . And since long-term total returns are a function of yield + dividend growth , that should help to accelerate AT&T's overall returns and make it a potential low-risk market beater. 
Click to enlarge Source: Simply Safe Dividends 
BUT even before this merger was announced I was fully expecting to have to wait until 2019 for AT&T to accelerate its dividend growth past the token $0.01/quarter per year we've been getting since 2009. 
After all, wireless telecom is a monstrously expensive industry, and AT&T recently spent $18.2 billion on AWS spectrum, $4.4 billion to expand into Mexican wireless (with another $3 billion in pledged infrastructure updates), as well as $49 billion to acquire DirecTV. All of this resulted in the balance sheet becoming more leveraged than management was comfortable with, as well as a credit downgrade from S&P (NYSE: SPGI ). 
So AT&T dividend investors were prepared to wait a few years for management to complete its cost cutting and DirecTV synergies in order to raise annual FCF to $20 billion, knowing that much of that would have to be directed to paying down the debt. 
Now that we are trying to buy Time Warner, we have the potential to achieve far higher free cash flow than before, and in a less capital intensive industry, which is a great diversification move. 
BUT it also means that we are going backwards in terms of strengthening the balance sheet. In fact Moody's (NYSE: MCO ) is now considering downgrading AT&T's credit thanks to how much additional leverage this deal will require. For example, starting in 2018, the new larger AT&T will have more than $9 billion in debt maturing every year. 
Combined with the new $14.5 billion dividend, you can see that the vast majority of the projected $26 billion in annual FCF the company will generate will be spoken for. That's especially true now that interest rates are rising and the cost of rolling over AT&T's maturing debt will likely rise steadily over time. 
Which means that, in the medium-term, ie next four to six years, AT&T investors shouldn't expect anything more than our annual $0.01 per quarter increase. Simply put, AT&T is paying a steep price to acquire quality, and faster-growing FCF, and we aren't likely to see dividend growth acceleration until the debt is brought down to a more reasonable level. 
Time Warner is selling out just as its hitting its stride 
TWX Free Cash Flow Per Share (Annual) data by YCharts 
Over the last few years, Time Warner has become very good at growing its FCF/share at a double-digit rate, which has resulted in nice dividend growth for investors of 11.2% CAGR. 
What's more, analysts were expecting Time Warner's dividend to grow at 8.1% over the next decade. And while such long-term forecasts always need to be taken with a grain of salt, in this case my own growth models agree that this is a pretty reasonable expectation. 
In other words, Time Warner investors are giving up superior dividend growth potential in order to own shares of a much higher-yielding stock, but one that, even under the best-case scenario, can't hope to deliver the same kind of income growth. 
Now, theoretically on a total return basis AT&T might be able to achieve better long-term returns thanks to the hypothetical faster payout growth this deal MIGHT allow, when combined with the much higher current yield. 
But that assumes many things, including that management achieves its targeted cost cutting/synergies, that AT&T's underlying businesses at least tread water rather than declines in the coming years, and most of all, that management doesn't go on another acquisition bender before the balance sheet is cleaned up. 
Or to put it another way, AT&T's current management seems to be trying to grow as quickly as possible and take on mountains of debt to do it. If the current trend of "buy something big, pay off a portion of the debt, then buy something else" continues, AT&T investors might be stuck with 2% annual dividend growth for 10 years or more as our debt levels continue to grow proportionally to our FCF. 
Trump threat is looking like it might have been hollow pandering 
In an example of the power structure I'm fighting, AT&T is buying Time Warner and thus CNN-a deal we will not approve in my administration because it's too much concentration of power in the hands of too few. -Donald Trump 
During the presidential campaign Donald Trump made a big deal about how he is against what he sees as too much media consolidation and would thus torpedo the AT&T-Time Warner merger. 
Add to this the broader net neutrality concerns raised by AT&T's potential to zero rate Time Warner content, (not count it againt customer data caps), which the FCC sees as an obstruction of fair competition , and you can see why many investors think this is going to end up just another failed mega deal. 
However, in recent days several events have transpired that seem to point to a higher probability of federal regulators approving the deal. 
For one thing, AT&T has said that it believes it can sell some Time Warner satellite liscences that might result in a deeper FCC review. 
In addition, the proposed appointment of Senator Jeff Sessions as Attorney General has some analysts expecting a far more lenient M&A environment under a Trump administration. 
Perhaps most importantly, the appoitnment of anti-regulatory lobbyist Jeffrey Eisenach to Trump's transition team, (specifically to help determine a new FCC position on zero rating, and net neutrality), could mean that Trump's anti AT&T-Time Warner stance was just campaign bluster; rather than something he intends to follow up on. 
Of course either way, it will likely take until the end of 2017 for us to find out whether or not the merger will be greenlighted, which potentially means that both AT&T and Time Warner shares will be under pressure during this time. 
As a long-term AT&T dividend investor I'm more than happy to wait for potential dips under $36 to accumulate to my existing position, because with or without Time Warner, AT&T remains a solid core high-yield position. 
Bottom line: Time Warner's higher FCF margin and faster growth could EVENTUALLY end up helping AT&T to accelerate dividend growth, but long-term Time Warner investors have less reason to cheer 
Don't get me wrong, there is still a significant risk that the Trump administration doesn't approve this deal. From the point of view of long-term dividend growth investors, Time Warner investors would likely benefit from such a scenario thanks to a faster dividend growth rate that would likely translate to superior long-term total returns. 
Meanwhile AT&T investors are, theoretically, getting the better end of this deal, assuming it winds up happening. And as long as management eventually solidifies the balance sheet, and diverts our growing river of FCF towards faster dividend growth, we are likely to do very well, especially at today's low share price, which makes for a an attractive price to add to our positions. Disclosure: I am/we are long T, BAC, MCO. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). posts.title: How Do Time Warner’s Technical Indicators Stack Up against Peers?
posts.text:
How the Time Warner Acquisition Could Benefit AT&T PART 13 OF 13 How Do Time Warner’s Technical Indicators Stack Up against Peers? By Shirley Pelts | Nov 17, 2016 3:18 pm EST Technical parameters 
Traders and investors analyze technical aspects of companies when making market entry and exit decisions. Moving averages and RSI (relative strength index) levels are among the most widely used technical parameters. 
Generally, an RSI of below 30 signifies that a stock is oversold, while an RSI of above 70 indicates that a stock is overbought. In this part of the series, we’ll look at Time Warner’s ( TWX ) technical parameters and compare them to those of other media companies. 100-day moving averages 
On November 14, 2016, Time Warner was trading 9.7% above its 100-day moving average of $79. In comparison, Viacom ( VIAB ) was trading 3.4% below its 100-day moving average, and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) was trading 5.1% above its 100-day moving average. CBS ( CBS ) was trading 7.4% above its 100-day moving average. Relative strength index 
Time Warner currently has a 14-day RSI of 58. By comparison, Viacom has a 14-day RSI of 60, which traders see as approaching oversold levels. 
Time Warner makes up 0.33% of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF ( SPY ). SPY has an exposure of 3.6% to the computers sector. {"metrics":["Open"],"tickers":["TWX","VIAB","FOXA","CBS","SPY"],"ticker_names":["Time Warner Inc.","Viacom, Inc.",null,"CBS Corporation","SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust"]} X

posts.title: How Is Time Warner a Good Fit for AT&T in Latin America?
posts.text:
Key Analysis of AT&T’s Acquisition of Time Warner PART 8 OF 14 How Is Time Warner a Good Fit for AT&T in Latin America? By Shirley Pelts | Nov 22, 2016 9:36 pm EST Time Warner in Latin America 
AT&T (T) has stated that its acquisition of Time Warner ( TWX ) would result in Time Warner’s representing ~15.0% of the combined company’s revenue due to the diversity of the premium content offered by Time Warner both in the United States and in Latin America. Let’s look at why AT&T considers Time Warner’s popularity in Latin America a big win for the combined company. 
Time Warner’s CEO, Jeff Bewkes, who was present on AT&T’s 3Q16 earnings call, stated that for Time Warner, Latin America was its biggest market outside of the United States. He further stated that the company’s cable networks in Latin America were the top-rated non-local networks in the region. He also indicated that Time Warner’s television programming was present across almost all pay-TV providers in the region. 
Time Warner also has Latin American programming aside from its US-based television networks in Latin America. Bewkes said that when it comes to the company’s acquisition by AT&T, “I think the match between the two of us in being able to help upgrade distribution and lead a real continuing buoyancy, just a secular take-up in Latin American countries of television services.” AT&T’s expansion into the Mexican and Latin American markets 
AT&T’s focus on growing its newly acquired Mexican operations appears to have been successful, helping it to offset ongoing US weaknesses in 3Q16. In Mexico, AT&T added 743,000 wireless net subscribers in 3Q16, and total Mexican wireless subscribers for the company have now reached 10.7 million. In Latin America, DIRECTV lost 48,000 video subscribers in 3Q16, mainly driven by falls in Colombia, Argentina, and Brazil. 
In 3Q16, AT&T’s DIRECTV pay-TV operations in Latin America had revenue of $1.3 billion, a quarter-over-quarter rise 6.0%. Time Warner’s acquisition by AT&T would result in AT&T’s combining Time Warner’s premium content with DIRECTV’s pay-TV operations in Latin American markets, which could boost its pay-TV subscriber base. {"metrics":["Open"],"tickers":["TWX","T"],"ticker_names":["Time Warner Inc.","AT&T Inc."]} X

posts.title: What Are Time Warner’s Valuation Metrics?
posts.text:
Key Analysis of AT&T’s Acquisition of Time Warner PART 13 OF 14 What Are Time Warner’s Valuation Metrics? By Shirley Pelts | Nov 22, 2016 9:36 pm EST Valuation metrics 
In this part of the series, we’ll look at some key metrics investors can use to compare values of media companies. We’ll specifically look at media valuation multiples, which are helpful in the valuation of conglomerates. 
The most common valuation multiples for companies are PE (price-to-earnings), EV-to-EBITDA, 1 PCF (price-to-cash-flow) ratio, and PFCF (price-to-free-cash-flow) ratio. 
Remember, price-based multiples take into account the value from a shareholder’s perspective, while EV-based multiples help investors understand the value of a company from a capital holders’ points of view. The latter metrics are forward multiples based on the expected values of the denominator after a year. Time Warner’s valuation compared to its peers 
As the above graph shows, Time Warner ( TWX ) has a forward PE multiple of 14.6x, which is high among its peers. Of these peers, Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Viacom ( VIAB ), and CBS ( CBS ) have forward PE ratios of 12.8x, 9.2x, and 13.1x, respectively. Only The Walt Disney Company ( DIS ) has a higher PE multiple at 14.6x. 
Time Warner has a forward EV-to-EBITDA multiple of 10.0x, while Viacom has the lowest forward EV-to-EBITDA at 8.4x. Time Warner’s value proposition 
Time Warner ( TWX ) is pursuing original programming for its Turner division, which bodes well for the parent company in the long term. The company is also pursuing a content licensing strategy in international markets instead of owning a network. This approach could reap rewards in the long term. 
Time Warner’s viewership is increasing for its digital platforms, including HBO Now, HBO Go, and HBO On Demand. This trend indicates that the company is poised to corner a significant share of the online streaming market. enterprise value to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization ↩ {"metrics":["Open"],"tickers":["TWX","FOXA","VIAB","CBS","DIS"],"ticker_names":["Time Warner Inc.",null,"Viacom, Inc.","CBS Corporation","The Walt Disney Company"]} X

thread.title: Time Warner commences public debt offering - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Time Warner commences public debt offering - MarketWatch

posts.author: Tomi Kilgore
posts.title: Time Warner commences public debt offering - MarketWatch
posts.text: Time Warner Inc. TWX, +0.11% said Tuesday it has commenced a public offering of senior debt, due 2027. The media company said it plans to use the proceeds from the offering for general corporate purposes, including the paying down debt. The notes will be issued by Time Warner, and guaranteed by Historic TW Inc., which is backed by Home Box Office Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. The amount of the offering was not disclosed. Time Warner's stock, which slipped 0.4% in light premarket trade, has run up 44% year to date through Monday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.53% has gained 7.7%.

thread.title: AT&T is optimistic about its Time Warner merger after talking to Trump's team (TWX, T)
thread.title_full: AT&T is optimistic about its Time Warner merger after talking to Trump's team (TWX, T)

posts.author: Nathan McAlone (nmcalone@businessinsider.com)
posts.title: AT&T is optimistic about its Time Warner merger after talking to Trump's team (TWX, T)
posts.text:
Getty/Alex Wong 
President-elect Donald Trump's transition team has assured AT&T that, contrary to Trump's campaign rhetoric, the proposed merger of AT&T- and cable company Time Warner will be treated without prejudice, according to the Financial Times.
"After talking with the president-elect’s team, AT&T executives are confident that their deal has a good chance of passing regulatory scrutiny, people informed about the conversation said," the FT wrote on Thursday .
There have been concerns that the government, particularly under Donald Trump, would move to block the $85 billion deal. Trump certainly helped give that impression.
“In an example of the power structure I’m fighting, AT&T is buying Time Warner and thus CNN — a deal we will not approve in my administration because it’s too much concentration of power in the hands of too few,” Trump had said while campaigning. 
This attitude seems to have softened, especially with Trump's appointment of two former officials with favorable records on the issue to his transition team. 
The FCC question But even before these recent developments, AT&T was telling Wall Street not to worry.
At RBC's Technology, Internet, Media and Telecommunications (TIMT) Conference in New York last month, AT&T management suggested  there wouldn't be any trouble with the merger. 
One big reason AT&T was optimistic at the conference is because the company believes the merger won't be under the jurisdiction of the FCC. 
"The only scenario in which the FCC would have jurisdiction is if Time Warner transfers certain broadcast licenses to AT&T," RBC analyst Jonathan Atkin, who viewed the presentation by AT&T's Chris Womack and Michael Black, wrote. "The company believes these licenses (primarily business radio licenses and licenses related to Time Warner’s ownership of the WPCN superstation) can be offloaded easily, obviating the need for an FCC review." 
That would mean the merger would only need to clear the Department of Justice, which AT&T is optimistic about. 
"The major difference between an FCC and DOJ review is that a DOJ review provides AT&T legal recourse while the FCC, if it chooses not to support the deal can defer the issue to an administrative law judge, a process that can last upwards of three years, usually resulting in the dissolution of the deal," Atkin wrote.
AT&T said it liked its odds, and expects the timeline on the merger to be 12-14 months.

posts.title: AT&T confident regulators will OK its Time Warner deal | Turner Broadcasting head gets candid about Trump, merger | Disney's record year in movies
posts.text:
By Trey Williams, MarketWatch
Senate antitrust, competition policy and consumer rights panel set to examine AT&T--Time Warner deal on Dec. 7
Good afternoon, MarketWatch readers. Welcome back -- after a much-needed Thanksgiving respite -- to another edition of the Swerve newsletter. As President-elect Donald Trump continues to put together a cabinet, the incoming administration has been fairly quiet on a potential approach to AT&T Inc.'s(T)proposed $85.4 billion merger with Time Warner Inc.(TWX), which Trump earlier vowed to block. The separate companies, however, have continued to make moves and news, and there's plenty else happening in the broader media and entertainment landscape. Sign up to receive Swerve: Time Warner, AT&T and the future of media (https://marketwatch.typeform.com/to/YStdOx).
Standard-issue scrutiny: AT&T executives reportedly met with members of Donald Trump's transition team, which told the telecom company its proposed merger would be scrutinized without prejudice, according to James Fontanella-Khan and David Crow at the Financial Times (https://www.ft.com/content/4c2d02fe-b7ea-11e6-ba85-95d1533d9a62). Executives are apparently confident the deal can pass regulatory review. The report put shares of Time Warner on a path toward a 15-year high in Thursday trades.
Candid news network: Despite the insults Donald Trump has hurled at the cable news network CNN, Turner Broadcasting Chief Executive John Martin isn't batting an eye at Trump's claims. "Please -- 'failing?' " he asked at a recent Recode event in New York. "I think [Trump] really cares about what CNN is saying."
(https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/803562827776720896)
Martin said he couldn't have been prouder of how CNN covered the election, before speaking about his parent company's proposed tie-up with AT&T. Asked if AT&T could take a selfish approach to Time Warner's HBO -- which has been one of the concerns surrounding the deal -- Martin said, "That's a moronic thought." He did concede there could be exclusive forms of content for AT&T subscribers, according to the Hollywood Reporter (http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/turner-ceo-says-donald-trump-cares-what-cnn-is-saying-talks-at-t-time-warner-deal-950956).
AT&T coming online: AT&T pulled back the curtain on its much-talked-about over-the-top online live TV streaming platform DirecTV Now earlier this week. DirecTV Now had been heralded as an industry-shifting addition to the landscape, but the new service came on the scene more in line with existing offerings, as MarketWatch reported (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/atts-new-directv-now-streaming-service-will-likely-cannibalize-cable-subscriptions-2016-11-29). And some analysts think the service will cannibalize traditional cable subscriptions.
And DirecTV's zero rating, meaning the service won't count against AT&T customers' data caps, raises concerns of stifling net neutrality (http://www.theverge.com/2016/11/29/13774648/fcc-att-zero-rating-directv-net-neutrality-vs-tmobile), writes T.C. Sottek at the Verge. The FCC sent AT&T a letter over worries of that zero rating in November. The company argues that the practice benefits customers, the Wall Street Journal reported (http://www.wsj.com/articles/in-reply-to-fcc-at-t-says-zero-rating-benefits-consumers-1479767200).
Disney's decade-old blueprint: Walt Disney Co.'s studio arm is on its way to posting the most successful year in film for a Hollywood studio, thanks to a dependable rotation of production studios in Pixar, Marvel, Lucasfilm and Disney Animations. The company is reaping the benefits of a strategy that began a decade ago with the $7.4 billion acquisition of Pixar in 2006 (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/disney-pixar-agree-to-74-billion-deal) and continued with deals for Marvel in 2009 and Lucasfilm in 2012 (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/lucasfilm-may-be-bargain-for-disney-2012-10-31).
"This is the first year where all five brands have films being released in the same calendar year and what you're seeing is the strategy [Bob Iger] certainly teed up through those acquisitions," head of distribution at Walt Disney Studios, Dave Hollis, told MarketWatch (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/disneys-record-year-in-film-has-been-years-and-billions-of-dollars-in-the-making-2016-11-30).
Judging competition: AT&T and Time Warner are on the Senate Judiciary Committee's schedule (http://www.judiciary.senate.gov/meetings/examining-the-competitive-impact-of-the-atandt-time-warner-transaction) for Dec. 7. The subcommittee on antitrust, competition policy and consumer rights will examine the competitive impact of the AT&T--Time Warner merger at 10 a.m. that Wednesday. A webcast will be available for the meeting on the committee's website.
Acquiring apps and audience: CNN has bought video-sharing startup Beme in a deal valued at about $25 million, as Wall Street Journal reporter Steven Perlberg wrote (http://www.wsj.com/articles/cnn-buys-casey-neistats-video-app-beme-1480353128). The social-media app, created by popular YouTube star Casey Neistat, will allow CNN to tap into its large, young and digital audience.
Download complete:Netflix is rolling out a download feature (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/you-can-finally-stream-netflix-without-the-annoying-buffering-2016-11-30) for some of the platform's movies and TV series. The new feature gives viewers -- finally -- a way to stream content on the go when cellular and/or wireless connections are spotty or even nonexistent.
Thanks for reading Swerve. If you're interested in keeping abreast of the AT&T--Time Warner deal and in keeping an eye on the future of media, sign up for the newsletter (https://marketwatch.typeform.com/to/YStdOx). For critical information before the markets open each morning, sign up for MarketWatch's Need to Know (https://id.marketwatch.com/access/50eb2d087826a77e5d 1/latest/login_standalone.html?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.marketwatch.com%2Fuser%2Fnewsletter), sent daily at 7:30 a.m. Eastern.
Follow Trey Williams on Twitter @Trey3Williams (https://twitter.com/Trey3Williams), and write to him at twilliams@marketwatch.com.
-Trey Williams; 1646ET

posts.title: With Dividends, Make 12% On AT&T Deal
posts.text:
With Dividends, Make 12% On AT&T Deal Dec. 2.16 
AT&T-Time Warner deal on track. 
SiriusXM wants to open Pandora’s box. 
Teleflex buys Vascular Solutions. Welcome to the Ma Bell issue of M&A Daily AT&T The $12.03 arb spread in the AT&T (NYSE: T ) acquisition of Time Warner (NYSE: TWX ) offers a 12% IRR if the deal closes by 2018 as I anticipate. Before it can close, it requires approvals by the DoJ, FCC and Time Warner shareholders. Each should and probably will grant their consent. This is a good deal for the target's shareholders. As for the regulators, it is not a highly problematic deal for a transaction of this size. If they stick to their statutory mandates and do not unduly politicize the process, it should be pretty straightforward. What about the politics? The President-Elect spoke badly of this deal (probably because of unfavorable treatment from CNN). However, there does not appear to be much follow-up to his adversarial statements. Focusing on the people Trump is picking for his antitrust and regulatory agencies, they appear to be highly professional and market-oriented. If anything, the most surprising thing about this team is that it is so entirely normal , similar to who other more traditional Republicans would pick. After AT&T management met with Trump antitrust leaders such as Joshua Wright, they had renewed confidence in their deal's prospects. Regardless of the President-Elect's prior comments, the incoming administration's agencies will be led by sound people who trust in market-based competition. President-Elect Trump's agency landing team includes Jeff Eisenach for the FCC and Paul Atkins for the SEC, CFPB, DFIC, and the OCC. Both would be my top choices for key roles. They could help rein in America's expensive and obtrusive regulatory burden. Watsi We raised $8,552 for Watsi so far. Thanks to everyone who has chipped in. I am grateful to all 89 donors. My goal is to reach $10,000 and 100 donors by Saturday. Let's help Watsi reach our next 10,000 patients. One day remains; please help!

posts.text:
Mark Cuban to Testify About AT&T-Time Warner Cinémoi's Ziman will also weigh in at Senate hearing 12/02/2016 12:58:00 PM Eastern Follow @eggerton 
AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson and Time Warner CEO Jeffrey Bewkes will have some high-profile company on the witness stand at the Dec. 7 Senate Antitrust Subcommittee oversight hearing on the proposed merger of their two companies. 
According to the witness list, released Friday, AXS TV owner and billionaire Mark Cuban will also talk about the deal with legislators, as will Gene Kimmelman, president of Public Knowledge, and Daphna Ziman, president of Cinémoi, an online video service. 
Ziman last week took aim at the merger , warning of its impact on independent and diverse video outlets, like hers. Want to read more stories like this?

thread.title: What to expect at this week's hearing about AT&T-Time Warner deal
thread.title_full: What to expect at this week's hearing about AT&T-Time Warner deal

posts.author: Melissa Repko
posts.title: What to expect at this week's hearing about AT&T-Time Warner deal
posts.text:
What to expect at this week's hearing about AT&T-Time Warner deal Filed under Technology at Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Dallas-based AT&T will go before lawmakers for the first time Wednesday to make the case that its $108.7 billion purchase of Time Warner should be approved. The deal would combine AT&T , the country's largest pay-TV provider, with Time Warner , a media and entertainment company with a valuable library of TV shows and movies. 
Would the merger expand competition or shrink it? At the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson and Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes will face questions along those lines. The hearing will have some celebrity star power, too: Tech billionaire and Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban will be among the witnesses . The lineup also includes Gene Kimmelan, president and CEO of Washington, D.C.-based consumer advocacy group Public Knowledge , and Daphna Ziman, president of Los Angeles-based fashion and film TV network Cinemoi. How to talk about the AT&T, Time Warner deal like an insider 
Stephenson will likely echo AT&T's position on the merger. He's said the deal is a vertical merger rather than horizontal merger and thus will not decrease competition. Vertical mergers combine companies that operate at different parts of the production or supply chain. In AT&T and Time Warner's case, AT&T is a distributor of content and Time Warner is an owner of content. 
Cuban, an advocate of the AT&T-Time Warner deal, has said it would allow AT&T to compete with tech giants like Google, Apple and Facebook as they continue to snap up digital content companies. But consumer advocacy groups like Public Knowledge have raised concerns that the mega-deal would put too much power in the hands of one company. AT&t CEO Randall Stephenson speaks during a House Judiciary Subcommittee hearing in Washington, on June 24, 2014. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Andrew Harrer. Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson has testified before to lawmakers about two other mergers. He'll head back to Washington, D.C. this week to speak about the Time Warner deal. Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg 
AT&T has been on the winning and losing side of mergers before. Stephenson went before lawmakers to testify about the company's purchase of DirecTV. The acquisition, completed last year, energized AT&T's business focus on entertainment and ultimately led to its interest in buying Time Warner. On the other hand, AT&T's attempted merger of T-Mobile, another wireless carrier, in 2011 faltered because of concerns that it'd hurt competition. 
Here's a preview of the themes that may come up on Wednesday: 
Zero-rating 
One of AT&T's current practices called zero-rating has come under fire ahead of the hearings. The Federal Communications Commission has written letters to AT&T , saying it objects to how the telecom provider waives data charges for its own TV apps. Customers who have wireless service and TV through AT&T can stream on AT&T's apps without it counting toward their data allowance. The FCC says zero-rating harms competitors by giving preferential treatment to certain content. To compete with AT&T's video streaming products, Netflix and others would have to pay AT&T to waive data charges through a "Sponsored Data" program. Other providers, including Verizon, are being scrutinized for similar use of zero-rated apps. 
Access to programming by rivals 
Time Warner owns prized content, such as HBO and its hit show Game of Thrones , Warner Bros. Studios and more. Its customers include TV providers like Comcast and streaming services like Hulu that pay to add networks or shows to their lineup. If AT&T buys Time Warner, it would own that content. Some consumer advocacy groups say that Time Warner might charge lower prices for AT&T and higher prices for other companies. Ultimately, those content costs would be passed on to customers' cable bills or subscription costs. 
Editorial independence of CNN 
CNN is one of the Time Warner networks that'd become part of AT&T, if the merger goes forward. The Atlanta-based news network has editorial independence under Time Warner. AT&T consultants and lobbyists have attributed President-elect Donald Trump's objections to the AT&T-Time Warner deal to his dislike of CNN's coverage of the election, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal . On Twitter, Trump has called CNN the "Clinton News Network." Stephenson has pledged to uphold CNN's editorial independence, but some are skeptical. Harold Feld, senior vice president of Washington, D.C.-based Public Knowledge, said he wonders if AT&T might push for more favorable Trump coverage to stay out of hot water with the president-elect. 
Privacy in the age of targeted ads 
AT&T executives say they'll use "next generation advertising" to offset the cost of new TV streaming services, such as DirecTV Now. It will do that in the form of personalized ads that target certain TV audiences or customized lists. With the merger, AT&T would own the pipes and the content, which would allow it to collect more data about viewing habits. Lawmakers may ask about safeguards for customer privacy. View Comments

posts.text: In November 2002, AOL Time Warner dropped "AOL" from its name and reverted to '''Time Warner'''. thread.title: A Dose Of Reality On The AT&T-Time Warner Merger
thread.title_full: A Dose Of Reality On The AT&T-Time Warner Merger

posts.author: Capital Flows
posts.title: A Dose Of Reality On The AT&T-Time Warner Merger
posts.text:
A Dose Of Reality On The AT&T-Time Warner Merger {{article.article.images.featured.caption}} Opinions expressed by Forbes Contributors are their own. Full Bio The author is a Forbes contributor. The opinions expressed are those of the writer. Loading ... Loading ... This story appears in the {{article.article.magazine.pretty_date}} issue of {{article.article.magazine.pubName}}. Subscribe On Wednesday, December 7, 2016 the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Competition Policy & Consumer Rights will hold a hearing on "Examining the Competitive Impact of the AT&T-Time Warner Transaction." Among the witnesses will be AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson, Time Warner CEO Jeffrey Bewkes and AXS TV Chairman Mark Cuban. AT&T unveiled a mega-deal for Time Warner that would transform the telecom giant into a media-entertainment powerhouse (KENA BETANCUR/AFP/Getty Images) 
There’s been a great deal of ink spilt over the proposed AT&T-Time Warner merger. Much of the commentary on the merger has been critical, with various authors expressing concern that the merger will limit consumer choice and lead to increased prices. Others have sounded alarm at the wave of cable and telecom consolidations we’ve seen in recent years and argued that bringing content and distribution together under a single roof will concentrate too much power in the hands of a single provider. In our current populist climate, it is perhaps unsurprising that an effort to join together two very large companies into one, even larger company would face substantial opposition. And indeed, when two companies merge, there is always concern that the resulting entity may use its increased size to raise prices or reduce service. When a company has a large enough share of the market, it has the ability to exercise what economists call “market power,” or the ability to charge a higher price for its goods and services because it doesn’t have to worry about competitors or new entrants swooping in and stealing away customers by offering lower prices. 
Watch on Forbes: AT&T Sings A Song To Video Lovers With Time Warner Deal When two competitors merge, economists call the union a “horizontal merger.” Two companies at the same level in the distribution chain decide to pool resources, simultaneously decreasing competition and increasing concentration in the relevant market. Regulators examine such mergers very closely to ensure that the reduction in competition will not lead to increased market power. The AT&T-Time Warner merger, however, is not a horizontal merger. AT&T and Time Warner are not competitors. AT&T provides wireless and broadband Internet service, while Time Warner creates movies, TV shows and other content that AT&T and other distributors transmit to consumers. AT&T and Time Warner operate at different levels of the distribution chain. Theirs would be a “vertical merger.” Economists tend to worry less about vertical mergers than horizontal mergers because vertical mergers don’t reduce the number of competitors in a given market. Rather, they integrate separate levels of the distribution chain. Following a vertical merger, Company A still has the same number of competitors as before. The difference is that rather than having to contract with another company above it in the distribution chain (say, a parts supplier) or below it in the chain (say, a retailer) to obtain a needed service, the company simply merges its operations with the other company. The hope in such a transaction is that the integration of operations will create efficiencies that will lower the company’s costs and increase profits, with some of those savings being passed on to consumers in the form of lower prices. That’s not to say that vertical mergers are worry-free. A company with market power in a given market could potentially try to use a vertical merger to extend its dominance into another level of the marketplace. Or it could attempt to cut off its competitors’ access to necessary goods and services by purchasing the firm that produces those goods and services and then refusing to deal with the competitor. Some commentators, such as Robert Bork, have argued that such “foreclosure” dangers are ephemeral and that any harm competitors might suffer would result only from cost advantages the merging company would enjoy as a result of increased efficiencies—cost advantages that would ultimately be passed on to consumers.
